DOC.HEAD: S&P: Inflation Will Remain Near 4 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Standard & Poor's Corp. predicted Friday that inflation will remain near 4 percent in 1990, after opening the year on a price surge inspired by recent cold weather. ``The December cold wave will leave us with a January hangover of higher prices for heating oil, other energy and fresh fruits and vegetables,'' S&P Chief Economist David M. Blitzer said in S&P's semi-annual consumer price forecast. ``But the damage will be temporary and prices will return to their recent 4 percent track.'' Blitzer said the soft economy will push consumer price inflation below 4 percent by late in the year. S&P is an investment advisory service that also rates debt securities and distributes a series of widely followed stock indexes. Through November, consumer prices have risen at an annual rate of 4.6 percent, enough to cause the Federal Reserve to move cautiously. ``Four percent inflation doesn't disturb most politicians or most people, but it does bother the Federal Reserve,'' he said. ``Even with a soft economy, the Fed will continue to watch the inflation measures very carefully.'' Inflation has been close to 4 percent since 1983, the first full year of the current record economic expansion. However, entering the eighth year of strong growth without a substantial decline in inflation is ``rather frustrating,'' Blitzer said. S&P also predicted that air travel will rise 2 percent in 1990, although bargain hunters should still find good deals; domestic auto prices may drop; clothing prices will stabilize or drop; gasoline prices will level out; and food prices will remain in check.
